channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Repeals Key Greenhouse Gas Finding, Erasing EPA’s Power to Fight Climate Change
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency rejected the bedrock scientific finding that greenhouse gases threaten human life and well being. It means the agency can no longer regulate them.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Rigorous scientific findings since 2009 have shown that greenhouse gases and global warming are harming public health.

item.title: What to Know About the E.P.A.’s Big Attack on Climate Regulation
item.description: The Trump administration has repealed the scientific determination that underpins the government’s legal authority to combat climate change.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Jenny Kane/Associated Press
item.media:description: E.P.A. administrator Lee Zeldin has claimed that previous administrations used the endangerment finding to justify “trillions of dollars” in regulations on polluting industries and its reversal will help the economy.

item.title: Trump Orders Dept. of Defense to Buy Electricity From Coal Sources
item.description: Mr. Trump is trying to revive coal, the dirtiest fossil fuel. At the White House, coal executives awarded him a trophy as the “Undisputed Champion of Beautiful Clean Coal.”
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump signed an executive order. On the desk beside him is a trophy labeled “Undisputed Champion of Beautiful Clean Coal.”

item.title: Portland Lawsuit Alleges Tear Gas Use by ICE Is a Health Threat
item.description: A novel lawsuit in Portland argues the chemicals are a health threat that have soaked into apartment walls, furniture and even children’s toys.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: An October incident outside an ICE facility in Portland, Ore. Residents across the street have sued over the use of tear gas.

item.title: With Latest Rollback, the U.S. Essentially Has No Clean-Car Rules
item.description: The E.P.A.’s killing of the “endangerment finding” caps a year of deregulation that is likely to make cars thirstier for gas and less competitive globally, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Apu Gomes/Getty Images
item.media:description: Transportation is the top contributor to U.S. greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Teddy Roosevelt’s Family Urges G.O.P. to Protect Public Lands
item.description: In a rare letter to Republican senators, four descendants of the former president oppose mining near a wilderness area in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.description: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Complaints to the U.S. Department of Transportation about the start-stop feature peaked in 2022 and fell almost in half by 2024.

item.title: Three Olympic Athletes Were Just Disqualified for a Novel Reason: PFAS
item.description: Their skis and snowboards tested positive for “forever chemicals,” slippery-but-dangerous chemicals now banned in the Games.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
item.media:description: Masaki Shiba of Japan was among the three disqualified. He said he knew of the ban and thought his equipment was in compliance.

item.title: New Research Absolves the Woman Blamed for a Dynasty’s Ruin
item.description: A Chinese king’s infatuation with a woman was seen as the reason that a golden age collapsed. Evidence suggests climate change and internal strife played bigger roles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Researchers digging to unearth remnants of what is believed to have been a fortified gate guarding an entrance to the capital of the Western Zhou dynasty, near Hejia Village, China, in December.

item.title: Trump Erased the Endangerment Finding. Here Come the Lawsuits.
item.description: The battle is expected to reach the Supreme Court, which is far more conservative today than it was when the measure was established.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump announced on Thursday that his administration would scrap the endangerment finding.

item.title: States Miss a Big Deadline, Ending Chance for a Colorado River Water Deal
item.description: After two years of negotiations, seven states failed to agree on reduced water use. A federal plan for the river could land in court.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lake Powell last July. Officials said that flows into the lake this year are 52 percent less than average, potentially rendering the dam unable to produce hydroelectric power by December.

item.title: What a Times Reporter on an Antarctica Expedition Eats in a Day
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong has spent more than a month on a South Korean ship in Antarctica with nearly 40 scientists from around the world. Here’s everything he eats in a day.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Leila Medina, Sutton Raphael, Rebecca Suner and Stephanie Swart

item.title: A Climate Supercomputer Is Getting New Bosses. It’s Not Clear Who.
item.description: The National Science Foundation said management of the machine, used by researchers for forecasts, disaster warnings and pure science, would be transferred to a “third-party operator.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Caine Delacy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The supercomputer is currently run from the National Center for Atmospheric Research headquarters in Boulder, Colo.

item.title: Meet the squad of graduate students supporting this expedition.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Chang W. Lee

item.title: Venezuela’s Natural Gas, Not Oil, Might Be a Big Early Prize
item.description: The South American country has natural gas that could be extracted and exported quickly, but U.S. sanctions, which are now being eased, have stymied development.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Daniel Wood
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: A liquefied natural gas terminal in Trinidad and Tobago, a country that has the infrastructure that Venezuela needs to bring its vast reserves of natural gas to market.

item.title: Floods. Smoke. Soaring Bills. Mamdani’s Climate Czar Has a Full Agenda.
item.description: Louise Yeung relishes the intricacies of policy debates and the magic of rom-coms. She lives in Brooklyn with her cat and two snails.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times

item.title: El Niño May Be Back This Summer, Bringing Drought and Floods
item.description: The powerful weather pattern is expected to shift into gear again around June, NOAA said, though its strength this time remains a question.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: David McNew/Getty Images
item.media:description: A storm in California during the last El Niño phase, in 2023. The El Niño weather pattern has far-reaching influence.

item.title: Why Living in China Is Like ‘Living in the Future’
item.description: A Times correspondent talks about life in China as it outpaces the United States in developing clean energy technology, self-driving cars and other innovations.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: -/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Wind turbine towers under construction in a factory in Jiangsu Province, China.

item.title: The Snow Sure Was Beautiful. Now Here Comes the River of Yuck.
item.description: Melting mega-piles of grimy road snow can release weeks worth of salt, oils (and dog poop) in what one scientist called a “triple whammy.”
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Associated Press

item.title: The Secret Plan to End U.S. Climate Regulations
item.description: A small group of conservative activists has worked for 16 years to stop all government efforts to fight climate change. Their efforts seem poised to pay off.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Lisa Friedman, Eric Krupke, Michael Simon Johnson, Anna Foley, Maria Byrne, Devon Taylor, Pat McCusker, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Evelyn Hockstein/Reuters
item.media:description: A coal depot in West Virginia. A scientific conclusion known as the endangerment finding has required the U.S. government to regulate the gases that result from burning fossil fuels like coal and gas.

item.title: Satellite Pictures Show Snow And Ice Across North America
item.description: For much of North America, the last month has been an icy, frozen trudge. But from the right vantage point, it had a certain beauty.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones and Leanne Abraham
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
item.description: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford’s closed battery plant in Glendale, Ky., which it plans to revamp to produce large storage batteries.

item.title: Laid-Off Battery Plant Workers Pin Blame on Ford, not Trump, for Lost Jobs
item.description: Ford Motor shut down a battery factory and laid off 1,600 workers after President Trump and Republicans gutted government support for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times

item.title: TV, It’s Not Just for Humans Anymore
item.description: Videos aimed at pets are drawing millions of views. But who’s actually watching?
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Julia Rothman

item.title: States Weigh Bills to Allow You to Make Your Own Electricity
item.description: Twenty four states are now considering legislation to allow small, plug-in solar power systems that connect directly into a wall socket.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Kt Kanazawich/Associated Press
item.media:description: A plug-in solar panel from the company Bright Saver installed in a Baltimore home.

item.title: ‘Finding Harmony’ Documentary on King Charles Shows His Longtime Concern for Environment
item.description: Environmentalism may have gone out of fashion on Wall Street and in the White House, but the British monarch says he remains deeply committed to the cause in a new documentary, ‘Finding Harmony’.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Tim Graham Photo Library, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Charles in his garden at Highgrove, southwestern England, in 1986. After he said he talked to his plants, he was widely mocked in the British news media.

item.title: The Conservative Activists Behind One of Trump’s Biggest Climate Moves
item.description: Four Trump allies have been a driving force behind the administration’s efforts to rollback a key climate regulation.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Russell Vought, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, is one of four officials who devoted years to charting roadmaps to undo climate and environmental regulations.

item.title: Climate Change Is Erased From Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence for Judges
item.description: After Republican criticism, a group that offers professional resources to judges withdrew a climate science chapter from its Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Chevron v Natural Resources Defense Council (Supreme Court Decision)
National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine
item.media:credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/Associated Press
item.media:description: J.B. McCuskey, the West Virginia attorney general, in Washington last month. He led the effort against the climate chapter in the judges’ handbook.

item.title: Behind the E.P.A.’s Rush to Repeal the Endangerment Finding
item.description: The agency is racing to repeal a scientific finding that requires it to fight global warming. Experts say the goal is to get the matter before the justices while President Trump is still in office.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura/Reuters
item.media:description: Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, at the agency’s headquarters in Washington last year.

item.title: Seals Are Recruited to Study the Ocean Under Antarctic Glaciers
item.description: The environment is changing rapidly around the melting Thwaites Glacier. Seals can collect data in waters that ships could never reach.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Bok Jin Kim, Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The tags themselves don’t seem to bother the animals, but Ms. Cheon and Mr. Chung agreed the tagging process tugs on some complicated heartstrings.

item.title: The Artist Nick Cave Couches His Critique in Dazzle
item.description: For “Mammoth,” a new show at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, he takes up contentious issues of race and climate change in beads, sequins and Lite-Brite colors.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik and Donavon Smallwood
item.media:description: The artist Nick Cave at his exhibition “Mammoth” at the Smithsonian American Art Museum. Behind a bounty of beads he recognizes that his topical show might yet face pushback.

item.title: A Campaign to Revoke the Endangerment Finding Appears Near ‘Total Victory’
item.description: A small group of conservative activists has worked for 16 years to stop all government efforts to fight climate change. Their efforts seem poised to pay off.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press
item.media:description: Russell Vought, speaking at the White House in 2019, was part of the core group that prepared the repeal strategy.

item.title: The Latest Victim of a Snowless West: Dog Sledding
item.description: Organizers of the Idaho Sled Dog Challenge said they would no longer hold a major competition after snow conditions forced its cancellation for a third straight year.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root

item.title: Students had Antarctica questions. We answered them.
item.description: Students sent in questions about our reporter’s journey to Antarctica, covering data recovery, clothing and more.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: Can Mountain Lions Survive as Humans Close In? California Is Trying to Find a Way.
item.description: A giant freeway crossing for wildlife is due to open outside Los Angeles this year. Here’s the story of one young cat hemmed in near the city.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Loren Elliott
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: War Came to Ukraine and Its Dogs Are Not the Same
item.description: Researchers discovered surprising changes to former pets along the front line of combat with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ham
item.media:credit: Tetiana Dzhafarova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A dog walked past damaged houses in the city of Svyatohirsk, Donetsk, last summer.

item.title: What’s Behind the Weird Weather That’s Dominated 2026
item.description: While iguanas were stunned by freezing cold in Florida, would-be skiers were looking at dirt on Utah’s slopes. Here’s what’s going on, and when it will finally end.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Danielle Brahier/Danielle Brahier, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A rare snowfall in Holt, Fla., on Jan. 18.

item.title: What’s Up With This Big Freeze? Some Scientists See Climate Change Link
item.description: A warming Arctic can stretch the polar vortex, a high-altitude air ribbon, one says. The “wobble” can disrupt the jet stream, causing extreme cold in the East.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Aristide Economopoulos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pedestrians walked the snow-covered streets of Jersey City, N.J., during last month’s winter storm. Some scientists say there is a link between a warming planet and the recent frigid temperatures.

item.title: Japan Ocean-Mining Test Successfully Hauls Up Potentially Valuable Mud
item.description: It’s the latest twist in the controversial global race to mine the deep sea for rare-earth elements and other valuable resources.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: SIP/Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, via Associated Press

item.title: Trump Opens Marine National Monument in Atlantic to Commercial Fishing
item.description: Off the coast of Cape Cod, the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument is a unique stretch of ocean that had been protected for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.category: Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument
Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument
item.media:credit: NOAA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A rare sei whale visiting the waters off New England in 2024.

item.title: A First Look Below Antarctica’s Most Menacing Glacier
item.description: Scientists on the Thwaites Glacier attempted to install equipment beneath the ice to better understand how it is melting. Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong walks us through their landmark experiment and the bittersweet outcome.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller, Stephanie Swart and Shafik Quoraishee

item.title: Contentious Weedkiller Gets a Green Light, in a Blow to the MAHA Agenda
item.description: The chemical, dicamba, is used to control weeds on genetically engineered crops. Courts previously had restricted its use.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Tom Polansek/Reuters
item.media:description: Dicamba, one of the most widely used herbicides in the United States, is often used on soybeans.

item.title: Studying Antarctica’s Ice From the Side of a Helicopter
item.description: The fastest way into the gaps between gigantic blocks of a broken-up glacier is by lowering instruments from above, through the door of a helicopter.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Climate ‘Superfund’ Bills Spread Nationwide, Despite Legal Battles
item.description: The laws aim to force oil companies to help pay for damage from global warming. Industry is gearing up for state-by-state battles.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Charles Krupa/Associated Press
item.media:description: Flooding in Vermont in July 2023. The state was the first to adopt a climate “superfund” law. Other states are now following.

item.title: Rebuilding the Lighthouse of Alexandria, Block by Virtual Block
item.description: An ancient skyscraper considered the seventh wonder of the world crumbled to ruin centuries ago. Now an ambitious archaeological project aims to reassemble it in 3-D.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Florilegius/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A 19th-century engraved depiction of the Pharos of Alexandria.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Texas Law Targeting Critics of Fossil Fuels
item.description: The court ruled that it was unconstitutional to bar state agencies from investing with firms that the state had accused of boycotting the oil industry.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Tony Gutierrez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Trucks at an oil field in Midland, Texas. A judge ruled that a 2021 law about investing practices was unconstitutional.

item.title: At a Bonobo’s ‘Tea Party,’ Scientists Find Hints of Imagination
item.description: In a playtime experiment, researchers found that our closest living relatives have the capacity for make-believe, too.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: When Venezuelan Oil Comes to the U.S.
item.description: In Mississippi, neighbors of a Chevron plant worry that an influx of Venezuelan oil could increase pollution. They want the company to pay to move them out.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chevron refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.

item.title: He Built a Server to Protect Indigenous Health Data
item.description: Joseph Yracheta was in charge of a repository that compiled and protected tribal health data. Then its funding was cut.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Tara Weston for The New York Times

item.title: Babies, Robots and Climate Change
item.description: It’s often assumed that lower birthrates could help slow climate change and A.I. disruption. The reality is more complex.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Administration Is Delaying Hundreds of Wind and Solar Projects
item.description: Federal agencies are delaying approvals for renewable energy projects on both federal land and private property at a time when electricity demand is going up.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Simon Simard for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has been halting or delaying federal approvals that were once seen as routine.

item.title: The Melting Continent
item.description: Today we look at an expedition to Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sifton
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
